title: South Carolina Lawmakers on the Confederate Flag
title_page: South Carolina Lawmakers on the Confederate Flag - The New York Times
text:
Debate began Monday in the South Carolina Senate on a bipartisan bill that would permanently remove the Confederate battle flag from a monument on Capitol property. If the Senate approves the measure, the debate will shift to the House, where passage is less certain.
Demands that the flag be taken down emerged after the June 17 massacre of nine people at Emanuel A.M.E. Church in Charleston, and experts described the legislative effort — in a state where Republicans control both chambers — as a reflection of a sudden shift.
“The court of public opinion has moved very rapidly here on this one,” said Scott Buchanan, the executive director of the Citadel's Symposium on Southern Politics. “The South Carolina legislature doesn't move rapidly on anything, so the fact that this has all come about is remarkable.”
The discussion continues to reflect deep divisions. Here are selected remarks by state senators engaged in Monday's discussion, updated throughout the day.
